RuntimeErrorAnalysis.Summary: Interfaces cannot be instantiated. Specify a concrete class as the type of the bean definition
RuntimeErrorAnalysis.SampleLogOutput: Exception in thread "main" org.springframework.beans.factory.BeanCreationException: Error creating bean with name 'com.springsource.example.Service#0' defined in class path resource [com/springsource/example/context.xml]: Instantiation of bean failed; nested exception is org.springframework.beans.BeanInstantiationException: Could not instantiate bean class [com.springsource.example.Service]: Specified class is an interface at RuntimeErrorAnalysis.RegExpPattern: Exception in thread ".*" org.springframework.beans.factory.BeanCreationException: Error creating bean with name '(.*)' defined in class path resource \[(.*)\]: Instantiation of bean failed; nested exception is org.springframework.beans.BeanInstantiationException: Could not instantiate bean class \[(.*)\]: Specified class is an interface
RuntimeErrorAnalysis.ProblemDetailHtml: In Spring, you configure bean definitions. Bean definitions represent instances in the object graph that you are wiring up. Instances can only be created of concrete classes. In configuration file '$2', you've configured an interface instead of a concrete class for the bean definition with name $1 (note that if you haven't given the bean a name or id a Spring-generated bean name turns up here).
RuntimeErrorAnalysis.SolutionDetailHtml: Open the file $2 and look for the bean named $1 (again, note that the bean might have gotten a uniquely generated bean name, if you haven't given it a name or id yourself). The type that has been defined for this bean probably is an interface. Interfaces cannot be instantiated. Therefore, change class attribute into a concrete class.
